title: Face of thug, 15, finally locked up for stamping on boy's head in fight over rugby ball
text:
News Face of thug, 15, finally locked up for stamping on boy's head in fight over rugby ball Calen Gaze was initially given just a community order but the Court of Appeal ruled he should serve four years in a young offenders' institute Share Calen Gaze had his sentence increased by the Court of Appeal (Photo: Police handout)   Thank you for subscribing!   15-year-old thug who "repeatedly and viciously" stamped on a child's head during a fight over a rugby ball has had his "lenient" sentence increased. 
Calen Gaze, now 17, was initially given just a community order when he left his 13-year-old victim with 10 broken bones in the skull that had to be repaired with titanium plates. 
The Attorney General argued his sentence was too "lenient" and Gaze has now been sent to a young offenders' institute for four years. 
He was first sentenced at Gloucester Crown Court in December, but this was reviewed by the Court of Appeal in London this week. 
After hearing the result, the victim's mother was overcome with emotion and said the relief was instant after a "traumatic" 16 months since the playground attack. His victim suffered permanent eye damage (Photo: Gloucestershire Live) Read More 
"My son will be so relieved, now he can start to move on," she told gloucestershirelive.co.uk . 
"After all this time I just feel completely different already. 
"Without this no lesson would have been learned. Not by the offender, not by the witness or my son or even the public. 
"Now we can move on with our lives a little easier. At least there is some form of justice. 
"You can't do what you did to my son and get away with it. I think my son will be able to move on now. The boy needed metal plates in his head to repair the damage (Photo: Gloucestershire Live) Read More Ex-boxer turned film hardman 'beat up cousin and attacked him with hatchet' because he confessed he loved him 
"After everything that happened I was not sure we would get a result. 
"But if nothing had changed it would have almost acted as an encouragement , that you can do this kind of thing with no consequences." 
The case was heard by Lord Justice Fulford, the senior presiding judge of England and Wales, alongside two other senior judges. 
After hearing the case from the defence and prosecution, Lord Justice Fulford said Judge Michael Harington had made an error in last year's six-day trial when listing the offence as Category 2 crime, rather than the most serious Category 1. 
He said the right categorisation would have left the judge with no choice but to jail Gaze. 
"These were terrible injuries that will have a fundamental change on his life. This was a sustained assault," he said. 
"These factors can only lead in our view to great harm and the use of a shod foot in these circumstances had a devastating effect, suggesting a higher culpability. The attack happened at King George V playing field in Gloucester (Photo: Gloucestershire Live) Read More Mum-of-seven who glassed woman and scarred her for life is spared jail because of her children 
"The offence is so serious neither a fine or a community penalty can be appropriate. 
"A community penalty would provide him the best chance of not re-offending and would be best for him in regards to his future. 
"But it is so serious a custodial term is necessary." 
A legal challenge to remove the attacker's anonymity to serve the public interest and act as a deterrent was also granted by the judge. 
There was little reaction from Gaze's family after the sentence, before they left shortly afterwards. 
The attack took place at King George V playing field in Gloucester in October 2015 when the victim and Gaze got in a fight over a rugby ball signed by Gloucester star Jonny May, before the victim was knocked to the ground and stamped on several times. 
The victim, now 15, had at least 10 bones broken in his skull and needed surgery to put in place a titanium mesh in his eye socket as well as a titanium plate. The Court of Appeal increased Gaze's sentence (Photo: PA) Read More 
He can never play contact sports again because of the surgery for fear of severing an optic nerve. 
He also has problems with his eyesight, has regular headaches, nightmares and needs regular pain medication. 
After the trial at Gloucester Crown Court in December, Gaze was found guilty of assaulting causing grievous bodily harm and sentenced to a three-year youth rehabilitation order and 240 hours of community service, while a friend was convicted of assault. 
But Gloucestershire Police's DC Benn Pockett said after the appeal: "This is the right response to the level of injury that happened and the nature of the incident. 
"The family were distraught by the initial decision and they have been driving this ever since. 
"The CPS (Crown Prosecution Service) got on board and are why we are here so we are very pleased with the result." Like us on Facebook
